app.title: ENEO - Evaluating Near Earth Objects Impacts
app.subtitle: Evaluating Near Earth Objects Impacts
app.description: Calculate immediate NEO impact effects on population and economy
app.metaDescription: ENEO: A web-based simulator to evaluate and visualize the impact effects of Near Earth Objects (NEOs) on population and economy. Calculate asteroid impact scenarios, including crater size, airblast, thermal radiation, and seismic effects.
app.metaKeywords: NEO, Near Earth Object, asteroid impact, meteor, impact simulation, ENEO, asteroid simulator, impact effects, crater calculation, space, astronomy, risk assessment, population impact, economic impact

hints.referenceDistance: Reference distance from impact point for analysis

effectMessages.noFireball: No fireball is created, therefore, there is no thermal radiation damage.
effectMessages.noThermalRadiation: no significant thermal radiation at the surface.

loading.calculatingEffects: This may take a few moments while we calculate impact effects and population data.

loading.simulatingEffects: Simulating seismic, airblast, thermal and ejecta effects...

tsunamiDisclaimer.title: Note on Tsunami Calculations
tsunamiDisclaimer.simplified: The tsunami effects presented here are based on a
tsunamiDisclaimer.explanation: . This model considers initial wave amplitude at the source and basic geometric spreading. The initial wave amplitude calculation is validated against the conditions described in the tsunami algorithm by Rumpf et al. (2016), serving as a basis for future enhancements. More advanced tsunami models were tested but proved too computationally intensive for real-time online purposes; their integration is a potential future improvement.
tsunamiDisclaimer.requirements: Accurate, operational tsunami modeling is significantly more complex and requires:
tsunamiDisclaimer.detailedBathymetry: Detailed bathymetry (sea floor depth, slope, and specific underwater features)
tsunamiDisclaimer.waveDynamics: Consideration of complex wave dynamics (e.g., refraction, diffraction, shoaling, reflection, and run-up)
tsunamiDisclaimer.hydrodynamicEquations: Advanced hydrodynamic equations and numerical simulations
tsunamiDisclaimer.limitationsBold: Due to these simplifications, the results from this model are for general informational purposes only and are not visualized on the map.
tsunamiDisclaimer.noSignificantEffects: No significant tsunami effects calculated by the simplified model for the current parameters, or data is not applicable.

tsunamiResults.noTsunamiOnLand: Impact on land: No tsunami generated.
tsunamiResults.oceanDepthNote: Note: Ocean depth at location reported as {depth} m.
tsunamiResults.transientCavityDiameterWater: Transient cavity diameter in water: {diameter} m

about.title: About ENEO
about.description1: ENEO (Evaluating Near Earth Objects Impacts) is a web-based simulator developed as part of the diploma thesis of
about.description2: at the School of Mining and Metallurgical Engineering, National Technical University of Athens (NTUA).
about.description3: It allows users to model asteroid impact scenarios and visualize their potential effects. The simulation calculates various physical phenomena, including
about.providingTool: , providing a comprehensive risk assessment tool.
about.vulnerabilityNote: Each effect is then processed for its potential
about.zonesNote: . These zones are used to model estimated casualties on global and national scales, and GDP per capita is used to provide a first estimate of the economic consequences.
about.gettingStarted: To get started, define the impact parameters or use the
about.buttonInstructions: button for a quick scenario. Then, select a location on the map to simulate the impact and explore its potential effects.
about.mobileNote: On mobile devices, remember to scroll down to view the full detailed effects (and scroll sideways until the Economic tab).

footer.developedBy: Developed as part of the diploma thesis of
footer.institution: School of Mining and Metallurgical Engineering, NTUA

economic.formula: Economic damage is calculated using the formula:
economic.explanation: This represents the direct economic impact based on casualties and national GDP per capita.

facts.chicxulub: The Chicxulub impact that killed the dinosaurs released 100 trillion tons of TNT equivalent—over a billion times the energy of the Hiroshima bomb.
facts.tunguska: The Tunguska event in 1908 was caused by a ~50-60 m object that air-burst over Siberia, flattening about 2,150 km² of forest and felling 80 million trees.
facts.kilometer: A kilometer-scale asteroid impacts Earth only about once every 500,000 years on average.
facts.chelyabinsk: The Chelyabinsk meteor in 2013 was only ~17-20 m across but injured ~1,500 people and damaged ~7,200 buildings, mostly from broken glass.
facts.vredefort: South Africa's Vredefort Dome is the largest confirmed terrestrial impact structure, originally ~300 km across, formed 2.023 billion years ago.
facts.dart: NASA's DART mission struck the 170 m-wide moonlet Dimorphos at ~6.6 km/s in 2022, shortening its orbit by 32 minutes—demonstrating kinetic-impactor deflection.
facts.meteorites: Meteorites fall into three broad types: stony (silicate-rich), iron (metallic Ni-Fe), and stony-iron (mixed), each with numerous subgroups.
facts.kineticEnergy: An asteroid's kinetic energy scales as ½mv²—doubling its velocity quadruples its energy—making speed as critical as mass for impact hazards.
facts.neoCount: As of December 2024, over 37,000 Near-Earth Objects have been cataloged, with 2,465 classified as potentially hazardous asteroids.
facts.mainBelt: Although the Main Belt contains millions of asteroids, their average separation is roughly 965,000 km—creating vast voids between objects.
facts.meteoroidSpeed: Meteoroids strike Earth at between 11 and 72 km/s; those above 20 km/s ionize the air ahead, creating bright plasma trails.
facts.hundredMeter: Objects ≥100 m diameter can release tens to hundreds of megatons of TNT equivalent, causing regional devastation.
facts.earthAccretion: Earth accretes ~54 tons of interplanetary material daily, totaling ~19,700 tons per year of dust and micrometeoroids.
facts.airBurst: Bodies <50 m often air-burst (like Tunguska), delivering more widespread damage than crater-forming ground impacts of similar mass.
facts.barringer: The Barringer Crater in Arizona is 1.186 km in diameter and 170 m deep, formed ~50,000 years ago by a ~50 m iron meteorite.
facts.hoba: The Hoba meteorite in Namibia is the largest known intact meteorite at over 60 tonnes, composed almost entirely of iron-nickel alloy.
facts.neoSurveyor: NASA's NEO Surveyor space telescope, planned for launch by 2027, aims to complete the survey of 90% of NEOs ≥140 m.
facts.phas: Of the known near-Earth asteroids, 2,465 are classified as Potentially Hazardous Asteroids—large enough and close enough to pose a significant impact risk.
facts.torino: The Torino scale rates NEO impact threat from 0 (none) to 10 (certain global catastrophe); only asteroid Apophis ever reached level 4.
facts.dailyMeteoroids: Approximately 25 million meteoroids enter Earth's atmosphere each day, ranging from dust-sized particles to occasional boulder-sized objects.

blast.highwayGirderBridges: Highway girder bridges will collapse; Vehicles will be largely displaced and grossly distorted and will require rebuilding before use
blast.multistorySteelFramed: Multistory steel-framed office-type buildings will suffer extreme frame distortion, incipient collapse
blast.highwayTrussBridges: Highway truss bridges will suffer substantial distortion of bracing;may collapse
blast.multistoryWallBearing: Multistory wall-bearing buildings will experience severe damage;may collapse
blast.woodFrameBuildings: Wood frame buildings will experience severe damage;may collapse

thermal.deciduousTreesAndSecondDegree: Deciduous trees ignition & Second degree burns

wind.ef4DevastatingDamage: EF4 - Devastating Damage (Institutional buildings severely damaged, all family residence walls collapse)
wind.ef3SevereDamage: EF3 - Severe Damage (Metal towers collapse, most walls in homes collapse)
wind.ef2ConsiderableDamage: EF2 - Considerable Damage (Trees debark, wooden towers break, homes shift off foundation)
wind.ef1ModerateDamage: EF1 - Moderate Damage (Tree trunks snap, windows break, facade tears off)
wind.ef0LightDamage: EF0 - Light Damage (Large tree branches broken, strip mall roofs begin to uplift)

fallbackMessages.lightOrNoWind: Light or no wind damage (Below EF0)

errors.invalidEnergy: Please enter a valid positive energy value.
errors.diameterRequired: Diameter must be 1 meter or greater.
errors.densityRange: Density must be between 1000 and 8000 kg/m³.
errors.velocityRange: Entry velocity must be between 11 and 72 km/s.
errors.entryAngleRange: Entry angle must be between 15 and 90 degrees.
errors.distanceRequired: Distance must be 1 km or greater.
errors.invalidInput: Invalid input. Please provide numeric values for all required parameters.
errors.couldNotRetrieveDepth: Could not retrieve depth data (out of bounds or map error).
